results.title: I live in fear = record of a living being = Ikimono no kiroku
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Shojiro Motoki and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: Kiichi Nakajima (Mifune) decides to relocate his family to the safe haven of Brazil from what he perceives is a nuclear holocaust. His methods of getting them there, by burning down their foundry, leads to his incarceration when the family commits him for being criminally insane. From the confines of the asylum Kiichi drifts into a fantasy world where he believes that the sun is an inferno created by the Earth when it exploded in a nuclear holocaust. ‘I Live in fear’ is Kurosawa’s blatant criticism of the perils of nuclear warfare, and was produced at the height of the Cold War when the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union were all experimenting with nuclear testing. The destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki was also a recent and painful memory. This a powerful study of patriarchy in Japanese society, and what Kiichi is willing to do to convince his family to support his beliefs. Although unpopular at the box office compared to his other films, Kurosawa thought of this film as one his most proudest moments, and thus deserves due consideration. Cast includes Toshiro Mifune, Kyoko Aoyama, Minoru Chiaki and Kamatari Fujiwara.

results.title: I like you: I like you very much
results.brief_description: This low-budget slice-of-life drama broke new ground in Japan in its representation of gay relationships and sex. The film centres on the shifting social and sexual relations between three teenage boys. The secure relationship between two of them, Shin and Yu, is jeopardised when Yu impulsively cruises a stranger waiting for a train and tells him that he likes him. This casual meeting sets off a series of sexual encounters. Shot in the port town of Kochi the film offers a candid portrayal of small-town gay lives and male desire. The first feature from high profile avant-garde filmmaker Oki, who directed, wrote, edited and photographed the film, it contains his trademark hand held camera work and informal visual style. The film falls into the Japanese genre of the “pink film” (or pinku eiga), a term that has been used since the 1960s to signify a variety of erotic, sado-erotic, and politico-erotic films, straight, gay, or in-between, whose small budgets, often brief running times, place them outside the genre of the mainstream feature. Cast includes Hisanori Kitakaze, Kazufumi Nishimoto and Hiroyuki Oki. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: I like maths
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Neville Stanley and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chalkface”.
Introduces three teachers from Corio West Primary School who have developed a series of mathematical “games” to make mathematics more relevant to real-life situations.

results.title: I left my country
results.creator_credit: Joseph Xuan-Minh Le, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: In 1982 Joseph fled from Vietnam and its Communist regime finally arriving in Australia in 1983 as a refugee. He tells of his journey, of leaving family behind, his resettlement in Australia and how seven years later he was finally able to bring his family to Australia.

results.title: I know where I'm going
results.creator_credit: Emeric Pressburger, Michael Powell and Archers Film Productions
results.brief_description: Joan (Wendy Hiller) has known exactly what she wanted since childhood, and all her dreams are to come true with her forthcoming marriage to a millionaire - but a storm strands her on a remote Hebridean island and the forces of nature conspire to change her mind. With its overwhelming sense of place and stunning visual effects, this most personal of Powell and Pressburger’s films is also one of their most perfect. “I had reached the point of thinking there were no more masterpieces, until I saw ‘I Know Where I’m Going’.” Martin Scorsese
results.creator_credit_for_label: Emeric Pressburger, Michael Powell and Archers Film Productions

results.title: I Know what you did last summer
results.creator_credit: Jim Gillespie, Stokely Chaffin, Eric Feig, Neal H. Moritz and Mandalay Entertainment
results.brief_description: Following their graduation, friends Julie, Helen, Ray and Barry get into Barry’s new BMW and head for the beach to celebrate the end of an important chapter in their lives. This sudden decision leads them on a path which will change their lives inexorably when they accidentally hit a pedestrian on deserted road. After the initial shock of what has happened has abated, they decide to toss the evidence, his body- into the ocean and swear secrecy to the event ever taking place. A year passes, the friendships have deteriorated, and strange things begin to happen. An anonymous note saying “I know what you did last summer” brings the accident on the road to life again, forcing the four friends to wonder whether someone has broken the promise of secrecy, or whether there was someone else on the road that day. Based on the novel by Lois Duncan. Screenplay by Kevin Williamson. Cast includes Jennifer Love Hewitt, Sarah Michelle Gellar, Ryan Phillippe, Freddie Prinze Jr, and Anne Heche.
